sources.name: Arbeitsschutzgesetz (ArbSchG)
sources.description: The German Occupational Safety and Health Act (ArbSchG) is the fundamental law governing workplace safety and health protection in Germany.
sources.authority: Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs (BMAS)
sources.notes: Primary legislation for workplace safety in Germany.

sources.name: Arbeitsstättenverordnung (ArbStättV)
sources.description: The Ordinance on Workplaces (ArbStättV) specifies detailed requirements for the design and operation of workplaces to ensure the safety and health of employees.
sources.authority: Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs (BMAS)
sources.notes: Implements the ArbSchG with specific technical and organizational requirements.

sources.name: Gefahrstoffverordnung (GefStoffV)
sources.description: The Ordinance on Hazardous Substances (GefStoffV) regulates the handling of hazardous substances in the workplace, including classification, labeling, and protective measures.
sources.authority: Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs (BMAS)
sources.notes: Crucial for industries dealing with chemicals and other hazardous materials.

sources.name: Betriebssicherheitsverordnung (BetrSichV)
sources.description: The Ordinance on Industrial Safety and Health (BetrSichV) deals with the safety of technical equipment and work equipment used in the workplace.
sources.authority: Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs (BMAS)
sources.notes: Covers machinery, pressure equipment, and other technical safety aspects.

sources.name: Allgemeines Bürgerliches Gesetzbuch (ABGB) - Arbeitsrecht
sources.description: The Austrian General Civil Code (ABGB) contains provisions related to labor law, including aspects of employer liability and general duties of care that can impact workplace safety.
sources.notes: While not solely a workplace safety law, it provides a legal framework for employer responsibilities.

sources.name: ArbeitnehmerInnenschutzgesetz (ASchG)
sources.description: The Austrian Act on the Protection of Employees (ASchG) is the primary legislation for occupational safety and health in Austria.
sources.notes: Comprehensive legislation covering all aspects of employee protection at work.

sources.name: Arbeitsstättenverordnung (AStV)
sources.description: The Austrian Ordinance on Workplaces (AStV) details requirements for the design, equipment, and maintenance of workplaces to ensure safety and health.
sources.notes: Implements the ASchG with specific technical and organizational measures.

sources.name: EU-OSHA - European Agency for Safety and Health at Work
sources.description: The official website of the European Agency for Safety and Health at Work provides a wealth of information, guidance, and statistics on occupational safety and health across the EU.
sources.notes: Excellent resource for understanding EU directives and best practices.

sources.name: EUR-Lex - Access to European Union Law
sources.description: EUR-Lex is the official online portal for European Union law, including directives and regulations related to workplace safety.
sources.notes: Primary source for all EU legislation.

sources.name: Arbowet (Working Conditions Act)
sources.description: The Dutch Working Conditions Act (Arbowet) is the fundamental legislation for occupational safety and health in the Netherlands.
sources.notes: Key legislation for workplace safety in the Netherlands.

sources.name: Arbobesluit (Working Conditions Decree)
sources.description: The Dutch Working Conditions Decree (Arbobesluit) provides detailed regulations and specific requirements for implementing the Arbowet.
sources.notes: Contains specific rules on risk assessment, hazardous substances, machinery, etc.

sources.name: DIN Standards (Deutsches Institut für Normung)
sources.description: The German Institute for Standardization (DIN) develops and publishes technical standards that often relate to product safety, machinery, and workplace equipment, indirectly contributing to workplace safety.
sources.notes: Many DIN standards are harmonized with European standards (EN) and are crucial for product conformity and safety.

sources.name: ÖNORM (Austrian Standards International)
sources.description: Austrian Standards International develops and publishes Austrian standards (ÖNORM) which often address technical requirements for equipment, materials, and processes relevant to workplace safety.
sources.notes: ÖNORM standards are often aligned with international (ISO) and European (EN) standards.

sources.name: NEN Standards (Nederlands Normalisatie-instituut)
sources.description: The Dutch Standardization Institute (NEN) develops and publishes Dutch standards (NEN) that cover a wide range of technical areas, including those relevant to workplace safety and product safety.
sources.notes: NEN standards are frequently based on or identical to European (EN) and international (ISO) standards.

sources.name: Bundesanstalt für Arbeitsschutz und Arbeitsmedizin (BAuA) - Publications
sources.description: The Federal Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (BAuA) provides a wide range of publications, including research reports, guidelines, and practical advice on various aspects of workplace safety and health.
sources.notes: Excellent source for practical implementation of safety regulations.
